text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 11.5.1, Legislative Affairs, 180-Day Letter Program.

This IRM section has been substantially revised due to the reassignment of the Government Accountability Office (GAO) and Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration Program (TIGTA) audit process procedures, which now fall under the jurisdiction of the Office of the Chief Risk Enterprise Audit Management Program. The title and purpose have been changed to reﬂect its
The following crosswalk details the disposition of the previous IRM subsections:

Content previously found in: Is now found in: 11.5.1.1 - Purpose IRM 11.5.1.1, Program Scope and Objectives (expanded to include Background, Authority, Responsibilities, Program Man- agement and Review, Terms and Acronyms, and Related Resources) 11.5.1.2 - Introduction to General IRM 1.29.1.2.1(1), External Accountability Office Program Entities with Audit Authorities (GAO) 11.5.1.3 - Introduction to the IRM 1.29.1.2.1(2), External Treasury Inspector General for Entities with Audit Authorities Tax Administration Program (TIGTA) Exhibit 11.5.1-1 Deﬁnitions IRM 11.5.1.1.5, Terms and Acronyms. Exhibit was deleted.
This IRM now contains procedures on the 180-Day Letter Program, formerly known as the 60-Day Letter Program under IRM 11.5.1.2.8 (4).
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 11.5.1, dated 08-21-2006, is superseded. This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memo OCRO-01- 0121-00001, 180-Day Letter Guidance, dated 01-07-2021.
AUDIENCE
Audit lead stakeholders and Enterprise Audit Management.

-Day Letter Program
) Purpose. This IRM provides information and guidance on the letters sent (
) the IRS to congressional committees in response to Government Program Scope and Office (GAO) reports. Objectives (
) Audience. Audit lead stakeholders and Enterprise Audit Management are the business units with primary responsibility for the subject matter of audits. (
) Policy Owner. The Office of Legislative Affairs (LA). (
) Program Owner. The Legislation and Reports Branch (LR) of the LA Office. (
) Primary Stakeholders. All IRS business units.
) When a GAO ﬁnal report contains recommendations for the IRS, letters are (
) be sent to the congressional committees having oversight over the IRS Background
days of the report’s issuance.

) This subsection lists responsibilities for EAM, audit lead stakeholders, and (
) LR branch. Responsibilities
) The EAM’s role is to provide a collaborative enterprise approach to the IRS (

) TIGTA/GAO audit management process. The EAM program is principally re- Enterprise Audit sponsible for: Management a. Serving as the single point of contact for all IRS audit activity. All audit correspondence (i.e., Notiﬁcations of Planning, Engagement Draft and Final Reports, etc.) between the IRS and our external bodies (TIGTA and GAO) come through this office. b. Maintaining a collaborative relationship with the embedded business liaisons to ensure audit information, concerns and issues are properly elevated for resolution and awareness. c. Engaging liaisons and Joint Audit Management Enterprise System (JAMES) coordinators by leading a Community of Practice. d. Elevating audits to IRS senior leadership that may result in external scrutiny, signiﬁcant ﬁndings or contain sensitive/signiﬁcant information. e. Notifying the audit lead stakeholder and the LA of the issuance of a ﬁnal report with recommendations for the IRS.
) The audit lead stakeholders’ role is to manage the audit process within the (

) business unit and respond to the subject matter of the audit. Audit lead Audit Lead Stakeholders holders are responsible for coordinating the draft letter response and the approval process within their organization.

Serving as the single point of contact for all IRS audit activity. All formal audit correspondence (i.e., Notiﬁcations of Planning, Engagement Draft and Final Reports, etc.) between the IRS and our external bodies (TIGTA and GAO) come through this office. Maintaining a collaborative relationship with the embedded business liaisons to ensure audit information, concerns and issues are properly elevated for resolution and awareness. Engaging liaisons and Joint Audit Management Enterprise System (JAMES) coordinators by leading a Community of Practice. Elevating audits to IRS senior leadership that may result in external scrutiny, signiﬁcant ﬁndings or contain sensitive/signiﬁcant information. Notifying the audit lead stakeholder and the LA of the issuance of a ﬁnal report with recommendations for the IRS.
Facilitating the

-day letter approval process with the business units, including routing the letter package to one of the deputies commissioner for signature by one of the deputies commissioner or the Commissioner and mailing the letters to Congress. Establishing the e-Trak control for the letter upon the issuance of the ﬁnal report by GAO, and providing it to EAM and the audit lead stakeholder for tracking.
E-Trak is the web- based servicewide document tracking application used for assigning letter cases to the audit lead stakeholder. The LR opens an e-Trak case with a due date that is

days after the date the GAO ﬁnal report is published, assigns the case to the lead stakeholder, and notiﬁes the lead stakeholder and EAM. When the package is returned to the LR with the signed letters, the letters are delivered to the congressional committees by the LA’s NCA. Upon conﬁrmation of delivery, the LR notiﬁes the lead stakeholder, EAM, GAO, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), and Treasury, and closes the e-Trak case.

case with a due date that is 180 days after the date the GAO ﬁnal report is published, assigns the case to the lead stakeholder, and notiﬁes the lead stakeholder and EAM. When the package is returned to the LR with the letters, the letters are delivered to the congressional committees by the LA’s NCA. Upon conﬁrmation of delivery, the LR notiﬁes the lead stakeholder, GAO, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), and Treasury, and closes e-Trak case. The following table deﬁnes terms used throughout this IRM: Term Deﬁnition A response to a GAO ﬁnal report with rec- ommendations sent to Congress. The IRS has 180 days from the issuance of the ﬁnal 180-Day Letter audit report to respond to Congress with the detailed corrective actions to be taken and time frames within which they will be imple- mented to carry out the recommendation(s). An examination of government programs, Audit operations, and/or ﬁnancial records. Audit is interchangeable or synonymous with review. A detailed description of how management Corrective Action will implement a recommendation to address the audit ﬁnding(s). A web-based service wide document tracking application system used for e-Trak assigning letter cases to the audit lead stakeholder.

page 3 The ﬁnal report is the ﬁnal version of the GAO draft report that may or may not contain modiﬁcations to the ﬁndings and recommendations identiﬁed in the draft Final Report report. The ﬁnal report contains the IRS management response to the draft report. Final reports are released to the public, unless designated as Limited Official Use (LOU). Audit Lead Stakeholder The business unit with primary responsibility (Note: Also referred to for the subject matter of the audit and for as “Lead”) speciﬁc audit process actions/tasks. A detailed description of how management will implement a recommendation to Planned Corrective address the audit ﬁnding(s). The PCA also Action includes due date(s) and the responsible official(s). Addresses the audit ﬁnding and provides Recommendation GAO comments to management that, when implemented, will correct the issue. , Government Accountability Office Audits. Government Accountability Office Final Reports with Recommendations for IRS. When a GAO ﬁnal report contains recommendations for the IRS, letters are sent to the congressional committees having oversight over the within

days of the report’s issuance. The letters contain updates on the planned corrective actions that address the recommendations, along with estimated completion dates, and are signed by one of the deputies commis-
sioner or the Commissioner. When the package is returned to the LR with signed letters, the letters are delivered to the congressional committees by NCA. (
) Within

days of the report’s issuance date, the letters are sent to the following committees: • The Senate committee on Homeland Security and Governmental • The House committee on Oversight and Reform • The Senate committee on Appropriations • The House committee on Appropriations (
) When a GAO ﬁnal report with recommendations for IRS is published, EAM notiﬁes: • IRS’s lead stakeholder for the GAO audit. • LR (
) The LR takes the following actions: a. Opens an e-Trak case with a due date that is
days after the date GAO ﬁnal report is published. b. Assigns the case to the lead stakeholder. c. Notiﬁes the lead stakeholder and EAM. (

) By noon on the day that is seven days before the due date, the lead stake- holder delivers the following to the LR: • Routing sheet (signed by the head of the lead stakeholder) • Note to Reviewers • Draft letter (

) By close of business on the day that is seven days before the due date, the LR delivers a signature package containing the following to one of the commissioner: • Routing sheet signed by the chief, LR • Routing sheet of the lead stakeholder • Note to Reviewer • Final letter (
